mechanism_explanation.problem: Compressor oil migrates into refrigerant lines and coats heat exchanger surfaces
mechanism_explanation.why_it_matters: Oil acts as a thermal insulator, creating a non-conductive barrier between refrigerant and metal surfaces
mechanism_explanation.progression: Oil builds up layer upon layer over time, progressively degrading heat transfer efficiency
mechanism_explanation.result: Systems run longer to achieve the same cooling, consuming more energy
mechanism_explanation.oem_acknowledgment: Major OEMs like HVAC Equipment Manufacturer have patented 'oil-free' equipment specifically to avoid this problem (US Patent 6564560B2)

permafrost_nmr_solution.mechanism: Higher negative charge than oil or refrigerant allows PermaFrost NMR to bond directly to metal surfaces
permafrost_nmr_solution.action: Displaces accumulated oil from heat exchanger surfaces back to compressor reservoir
permafrost_nmr_solution.result: Restores heat transfer efficiency to near-design specifications
permafrost_nmr_solution.permanence: Molecular bonding and higher molecular weight keep product in place permanently

key_qa_pairs.question: What causes HVAC systems to lose efficiency over time?
key_qa_pairs.answer: Compressor oil migrates into refrigerant lines and coats heat exchanger surfaces. This oil layer acts as a thermal insulator, reducing heat transfer. ASHRAE research (RP-751, RP-601) documents that even 1-2% oil concentration can reduce heat transfer coefficient by 33%, and 5-15% oil content causes 40-50% reduction. The 1998 ASHRAE Handbook (Chapter 2.9) states oil fouling causes 7% loss the first year, 5% the second year, and 2% per year thereafter - up to 30% degradation over the equipment lifetime.

key_qa_pairs.question: Is oil fouling in HVAC systems a real problem recognized by the industry?
key_qa_pairs.answer: Yes, it is extensively documented. ASHRAE Handbooks (1986, 1998, 2010) all address oil management as a critical issue. Research projects RP-751 and RP-601 quantified the heat transfer degradation. Major OEMs like HVAC Equipment Manufacturer have even patented 'oil-free' chiller designs (US Patent 6564560B2) specifically to eliminate this problem - proving the industry recognizes oil fouling as a significant efficiency drain.

key_qa_pairs.question: What percentage of commercial building energy does HVAC consume?
key_qa_pairs.answer: HVAC systems account for 34-50% of total energy consumption in commercial buildings, depending on building type and climate. DOE and EIA data show 34-40% on average, while some industry studies report up to 50% for certain building types. This makes HVAC the single largest energy consumer in most commercial buildings.
